p: document.documentElement.className="client-js";RLCONF={"wgCanonicalNamespace":"","wgCanonicalSpecialPageName":!1,"wgNamespaceNumber":0,"wgPageName":"Uptown..._It's_Hot!","wgTitle":"Uptown... It's Hot!","wgCurRevisionId":903936435,"wgRevisionId":903936435,"wgArticleId":19758414,"wgIsArticle":!0,"wgIsRedirect":!1,"wgAction":"view","wgUserName":null,"wgUserGroups":["*"],"wgCategories":["CS1 errors: markup","Articles with IBDb links","Broadway musicals","1986 musicals","Revues"],"wgBreakFrames":!1,"wgPageContentLanguage":"en","wgPageContentModel":"wikitext","wgSeparatorTransformTable":["",""],"wgDigitTransformTable":["",""],"wgDefaultDateFormat":"dmy","wgMonthNames":["","January","February","March","April","May","June","July","August","September","October","November","December"],"wgMonthNamesShort":["","Jan","Feb","Mar","Apr","May","Jun","Jul","Aug","Sep","Oct","Nov","Dec"],"wgRelevantPageName":"Uptown..._It's_Hot!","wgRelevantArticleId":19758414,"wgRequestId":

Uptown... It's Hot! was a 1986 Broadway play created, directed, choreographed by and starring Maurice Hines. Performed at the Lunt-Fontanne Theatre, the play was a musical anthology chronicling the history of African-American music in the United States.

Although the music garnered praise, the play received generally unfavorable reviews.[1][2][3] New York Times critic Frank Rich called it "the theatrical equivalent of a telephone-booth-stuffing contest" and "an orgy of grotesque and sometimes necrophiliac mimicry."[1] The play did, however, earn Hines a Tony Award nomination for Best Performance by a Leading Actor in a Musical.[4]
Uptown... It's Hot! ran from January 28 to February 16, 1986, ending its run after 24 performances.[5]

^ a b Frank Rich (January 29, 1986). "'Uptown' a musical".
